title: Canterbury's Lake Pegasus closed due to algal bloom
text:
Canterbury's Lake Pegasus closed due to algal bloom Last updated 14:35, February 14 2017 DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Lake Pegasus is at the heart of the North Canterbury township. 
Lake Pegasus has been closed due to a bloom of potentially toxic algae. 
The man-made lake is at the centre of the North Canterbury township and used by swimmers and kayakers. 
It is the third year in a row the lake has had to close due to an algal bloom. JONATHAN LEASK/FAIRFAX NZ 
People swimming in the lake early last year. 
The Waimakariri District Council said the lake was closed until further notice. 
READ MORE * North Canterbury's Lake Pegasus closed due to possible algae bloom 
Canterbury medical officer of health Dr Ramon Pink said the blue-green algae (planktonic cyanobacteria) produce a dangerous toxin. 
"People and animals, particularly dogs, should avoid contact with Lake Pegasus until the health warning has been lifted. 
"Exposure may cause skin rashes, nausea, stomach cramps, tingling and numbness around the mouth and fingertips. If you experience any of these symptoms visit your doctor immediately and please let them know you have had contact with the lake water." 
The health of the lake has been a sore point in the community. 
The lake's resource consent, issued in 2006, requires it only be kept to a secondary contact standard. Ad Feedback 
At the time, hearing commissioners said it was unlikely to maintain a swimmable standard. 
Despite not being designed for swimming, the lake has beaches and hosts events such as triathlons which involve people swimming in the lake.
